text.p: True or False: No linear transformation [mathjaxinline]T: \mathbb R^8 \rightarrow \mathbb R^6[/mathjaxinline] can be into.
True or False: Every linear transformation [mathjaxinline]T: \mathbb R^6 \rightarrow \mathbb R^8[/mathjaxinline] must be into.

solution.font:
Since [mathjaxinline]8>6[/mathjaxinline], by the proposition, a transformation [mathjaxinline]T: \mathbb R^8 \rightarrow \mathbb R^6[/mathjaxinline] cannot be into.
If [mathjaxinline]T: \mathbb R^6 \rightarrow \mathbb R^8[/mathjaxinline], [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] may be into, or it may not be. For an example of the latter, take [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] to be the linear transformation taking every [mathjaxinline]v\in \mathbb R^6[/mathjaxinline] to the zero vector, [mathjaxinline]\mathbf{0}\in \mathbb R^8[/mathjaxinline]. In this case, every vector in [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^6[/mathjaxinline] is in the kernel of [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline], and thus [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is not into.
